diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs), including Chlamydia and Gonorrhea
Mononucleosis (Infectious Mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus)
Cervical Cancer or pre-cancerous conditions leading to lymphadenopathy with secondary infection causing pyuria
Pharyngitis, bacterial or viral, which could be associated with lymphadenopathy
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection or Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) with opportunistic infections
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (due to Enteroviruses)
Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Dengue fever, Ebola)
Viral infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Parvovirus B19)
Sjögren's Syndrome with central nervous system involvement
Cancer (various types, depending on specific symptoms and findings)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect kidneys (lupus nephritis), cause inflammation of the pericardium (acute pericarditis) and can lead to pericardial effusion. CNS involvement might explain delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion, with possible renal impairment. CNS involvement can lead to symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.rationale: Severe renal failure (nephritis) can lead to uremia, which might cause pericardial effusion (uremic pericarditis) and central nervous system manifestations like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatic fever can cause carditis (including pericarditis), can lead to nephritis, and in severe cases might cause CNS involvement including manifestations of delirium.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: This infection can indirectly cause nephritis through immune complex deposition, acute pericarditis through spread of infection, and delirium due to systemic infection or emboli.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can cause symptoms similar to lupus, including acute pericarditis, nephritis, and possible CNS effects that could result in delirium.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, presenting with acute pericarditis, nephritis, and potential CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Although more rare, TB can lead to pericarditis and pericardial effusion, renal impairment, and systemic symptoms that may include delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can affect the heart (leading to pericarditis), kidneys (nephritis), and have neurological manifestations, though delirium is rare.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers or metastasis can indirectly cause nephritis, pericardial effusion, and acute pericarditis. Metabolic disturbances or brain metastasis might lead to delirium.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with renal and neurological involvement
Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to symptoms like decreased libido, hypersensitivity reactions, and insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest, which can manifest as decreased libido, hypersensitivity to certain stimuli, insomnia, and sometimes altered taste perceptions.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental illnesses that cause intense anxiety and fear, often accompanied by insomnia, decreased libido, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: A state of prolonged tension from internal or external stressors, which can lead to symptoms like decreased libido, insomnia, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency in red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to symptoms including dysgeusia (altered taste), decreased libido, and insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of zinc in the diet can lead to a variety of symptoms, including dysgeusia (altered taste), decreased libido, and possibly insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions to allergens, which can include hypersensitivity reactions, and in very severe cases, might indirectly contribute to stress that aggravates insomnia and decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various disorders affecting the endocrine system, such as diabetes or Addison's disease, can manifest with symptoms like decreased libido, hypersensitivity reactions, and insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can lead to side effects including decreased libido, insomnia, hypersensitivity reactions, and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Insomnia
diagnoses.description: A long-term pattern of difficulty sleeping that can lead to or exacerbate other symptoms such as decreased libido and hypersensitivity reactions due to chronic fatigue and stress.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Glycemic lability is a hallmark symptom.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.reasoning: May cause epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to increased blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to hypertension and therefore epistaxis; also affects sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.reasoning: Frequent waking is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to easy bleeding due to impaired coagulation; also associated with glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Coagulopathy (e.g., Hemophilia, Von Willebrand Disease)
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly responsible for easy bleeding and could contribute to epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.reasoning: Can exacerbate or contribute to diabetes mellitus, sleep apnea, and chronic back pain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause chronic back pain and, in severe cases, affect sleep due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased red cell count can lead to hyperviscosity and bleeding issues, including epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause chronic pain, including back pain, and is associated with renal issues, thereby indirectly contributing to glycemic lability and easy bleeding.

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal infections (such as Yersinia, Salmonella, Campylobacter)
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Eating Disorder (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can lead to irregularities in menstruation and hormonal imbalances that might result in miscarriages. Obesity, a common manifestation in PCOS, can contribute to obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can lead to a variety of symptoms including weight gain (potentially exacerbating obstructive sleep apnea), menstrual irregularities (which could increase the risk of miscarriage), and general bloating.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress or Anxiety
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic stress can lead to a multitude of physical symptoms, including exacerbating or leading to conditions like interstitial cystitis. Stress can also impact hormone levels and sleep patterns, contributing to sleep apnea and potentially increasing the risk of miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.reasoning: Obesity is a leading cause of obstructive sleep apnea due to excess weight putting pressure on the chest and neck, affecting breathing during sleep. Obesity can also contribute to PCOS, leading to a higher risk of miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune disorders can present with symptoms such as warts (due to immune system dysfunction), miscarriages (antiphospholipid syndrome, for example), and potentially contribute to conditions like interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.reasoning: Uncontrolled diabetes can lead to a wide range of complications including obesity, which in turn can increase the risk of obstructive sleep apnea. High blood sugar levels might also worsen conditions like interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
diagnoses.reasoning: HPV can directly cause warts and has been suggested to potentially have a role in miscarriages. While it may not directly cause sleep apnea or bloating, its complications and treatments could indirectly affect the patient's overall health condition.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome could cause weight gain and central obesity, leading to obstructive sleep apnea, alongside other symptoms such as increased risk of miscarriage due to hormonal imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: Depression can have a profound effect on physical health, potentially contributing to obesity and sleep apnea, exacerbating symptoms like bloating, and impacting hormonal balance, which may affect fertility and increase miscarriage risk.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reasoning: While IBS primarily affects the digestive system causing symptoms like bloating, it can impact overall health and well-being, influencing sleep patterns and potentially contributing to stress levels that may exacerbate other conditions.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm as part of a neurologic disorder
Vitamin and mineral deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Zinc)
Gastrointestinal disorders associated with eosinophilic gastrointestinal diseases (EGID)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Allergic reaction (to food, medication, or other allergens)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. Symptoms can include photophobia, scotoma, and sometimes aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition occurring due to interrupted or reduced blood supply to part of the brain, causing damage to brain cells. Symptoms can include weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to varying levels of physical and cognitive disability. Symptomatology can include weakness, nausea (from medication or as a symptom of MS relapse), photophobia, and scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can be cancerous or benign. Symptoms can vary widely but may include nausea, weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms can include nausea, weakness, photophobia, and in severe cases, altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A type of stroke caused by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, nausea, photophobia, and sometimes vision changes and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the temporal arteries which can cause headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, visual disturbances, and sometimes symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica such as weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Specific types of seizures may present with aphasia, visual disturbances like scotoma, or sensations of nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare type of ischemic stroke occurring during a migraine with aura attack, involving neurological symptoms including weakness, visual disturbances, and sometimes aphasia that do not resolve within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nervous system, leading to weakness, numbness, and sometimes autonomic dysfunction which can manifest as nausea.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)
Viral infections (e.g., dengue fever, Zika virus)
Immunobullous diseases (e.g., bullous pemphigoid, pemphigus vulgaris)
Chronic liver disease leading to coagulopathies
Hepatitis B or C Associated Cryoglobulinemia
Cancer (various types, including lung cancer and lymphoma)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with ITP)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
